title: APM Traces Ingestion Reasons Overview
description:
## APM Ingestion reasons overview

Multiple mechanisms are responsible for choosing if spans generated by your applications are sent to Datadog (ingested). The logic behind these mechanisms lie in the tracing libraries and in the Datadog Agent. Depending on the configuration, all or some the traffic generated by instrumented services is ingested.

To each span ingested, there is attached a unique **ingestion reason** referring to one ingestion mechanism. Ingestion [estimated usage metrics](https://docs.datadoghq.com/tracing/trace_ingestion/usage_metrics/) are tagged by ingestion_reason.

Read more about ingestion mechanisms in the [documentation](https://docs.datadoghq.com/tracing/trace_ingestion/mechanisms/)

definition.title: Ingestion volume breakdown by ingestion reason
Month over month ingestion volume by ingestion reason
Contribution of ingestion reasons to the ingestion volume by env and service
Total amount of ingested bytes per Service and Ingestion Reason

definition.content:
## Head-based sampling definition
***ingestion_reason:auto*** & ***ingestion_reason:rule***

The default sampling mechanism is called head-based sampling. The decision of whether to keep or drop a trace is made at the very beginning of the trace, at the start of the root span. This decision is then propagated to other services as part of their request context.

Because the decision is made at the beginning of the trace and then conveyed to all parts of the trace, the trace is guaranteed to be kept or dropped as a whole.

### Notes

- A higher level of head-based sampling decision will guarantee more complete traces.
- Reducing the overall volume of head based sampling will not always impair visibility since error and rare spans will still be captured

Read more about head-based sampling in the [documentation](https://docs.datadoghq.com/tracing/trace_ingestion/mechanisms/?tab=environmentvariables#head-based-sampling)

definition.title: Contribution to overall volume compared to month before
Span volume by env and service

queries.query: sum:datadog.estimated_usage.apm.ingested_bytes{$env AND $service AND $ingestion_reason AND (ingestion_reason:rule OR ingestion_reason:auto)} by {env,service}.as_count()
queries.name: query1

definition.content:
## Agent configuration
***ingestion_reason:auto***

Learn how to [configure sampling in the agent](https://docs.datadoghq.com/tracing/trace_ingestion/mechanisms/?tab=environmentvariables#head-based-sampling)

## Tracing Library configuration
***ingestion_reason:rule***

Learn how to [configure sampling in the tracing libraries](https://docs.datadoghq.com/tracing/trace_ingestion/mechanisms/?tab=environmentvariables#in-tracing-libraries-user-defined-rules)

# Error Traces 

***ingestion_reason:error***

For traces not caught by the head-based sampling, an agent mechanism indexes error spans, in order to provide visibility on potential system failures.

By default, each agent samples 10 errors per second.

definition.title: Span volume by env and service

definition.content:
# Rare Traces

***ingestion_reason:rare***

For traces not caught by the head-based sampling, an agent mechanism indexes rare spans, in order to keep visibility on your system as a whole, by making sure that low-traffic services and resources are still monitored.

It catches all combinations of `service`, `name`, `resource`, `http.status_code` and `error.type`.

By default, each agent samples 5 rare traces per second.

definition.title: Span volume by env and service

definition.content:
# App Analytics

***ingestion_reason:analytics***

[App Analytics a deprecated mechanism](https://docs.datadoghq.com/tracing/trace_ingestion/mechanisms/#single-spans-app-analytics)

With App Analytics, spans are ingested as single spans without the full trace. Use head-based sampling instead to ensure full traces are kept.

definition.title: Span volume by env and service

definition.content:
# Force keep and drop

***ingestion_reason:manual***

The head-based sampling mechanism can be overridden at the tracing library level. 

For example: 
- If you need to monitor a critical transaction, you can force the associated trace to be kept.
- For unnecessary or repetitive information like health checks, you can force the trace to be dropped.

definition.title: Span volume by env and service

definition.content:
# RUM 

***ingestion_reason:rum***


If you are using Datadog RUM in addition of Datadog APM you have the capacity to bind the two product together in order to gain end to end visibility.

Traces are generated from browser services in order to track the end-to-end requests from front end to back end.

See the [Connect RUM and Traces](https://docs.datadoghq.com/real_user_monitoring/connect_rum_and_traces/) documentation

# Synthetics

***ingestion_reason:synthetics or ingestion_reason:synthetics_browser***


If you are using Datadog Synthetics product in addition of Datadog APM you have the capacity to bind the two product together in order to gain end to end visibility.

Traces are generated from API tests and browser tests if services are instrumented with APM 

See the [Connect Synthetic and Traces](https://docs.datadoghq.com/synthetics/apm/) documentation.

# Serverless 

***ingestion_reason:serverless or ingestion_reason:xray***


If you are using Datadog Serverless in addition of Datadog APM Traces from your AWS lambda functions and AWS Xray are automatically kept for end to end visibility.

# Application Security 

***ingestion_reason:appsec***


If you are using Datadog Application security in addition of Datadog APM all spans monitored by Application security are kept
